.  It was formed in 2005 by the merger of many towns: Chokai, Higashi Yuri, Nishime, Iwaki, Honjo, Yashima, and Yuri.

Yurihonjo was formed by a merger of several towns, yet those towns are still largely oriented around themselves.  And since Yurihonjo is very large, in terms of area, people living in the SE may know nothing about people living in the NW, for example.
(本荘) is in the west of Yurihonjo.  To the south of Honjo is
(西目).  To the north of Honjo are
(東由利) is east of Honjo.  In the SE are
(鳥海).  Chokai is composed of three villages,

Honjo, located at the heart of Yurihonjo, is a city surrounded by hills ("Dewa-kyuryo"), plateaus ("Yuri-hara") and the sea. It is believed that the area of Honjo was under the sea about 1,000,000 years ago and that its higher zones started gradually emerging some 500,000 years later. By 3000 B.C., some large villages had been formed at the foot of the Dewa-kyuryo.

The name

appeared for the first time in "Azumakagami", a book written around 1200. The Yuri clan was a powerful family who governed Nikaho, Yashima, Koyoshi and other neighboring districts. Their territories, however, were confiscated by the government in 1213, and for the following 400 years up to 12 clans ruled over the area together.  In the early 17th century, the area was disputed between the government and the local clans. It finally became the property of the Rokugo clan from Ibaraki in 1623 and remained so for about 250 years.

There once was a castle in Honjo, located on the site of today's Honjo Park. As a matter of fact, the old way of writing Honjo, 本城, means "main castle". However this castle can no longer be seen as it was burnt down in 1868 by the members of the Rokugo clan themselves at the end of their reign.

On April 1, 1889, the district officially gained the name "Honjo Town". On March 31, 1954, the town merged with the villages of Koyoshi, Otomo, Ishizawa, Minami-utetsu, Kita-utetsu and Matsugazaki. Then, on March 22, 2005, Honjo Town merged again with 7 other small towns of the area to become "Yurihonjo City".

July is the rainy season, with regular afternoon showers.  The spring and summer before and after that have less rain, and are therefore good for outdoor activities.  In November, cold weather thunder storms are said to mark the end of fall and the beginning of
(a local fish) season.  In the winter, the coastal areas of Yurihonjo get a little snow, and the inland areas get a lot, which makes for good skiing and snowboarding.
Depending where you're going, a car is probably your best bet.
Within Akita, cars are the most convenient way to get around.  Highway 7 connects Honjo with
to the north, by way of Iwaki, and
to the south, by way of Nishime.  Highway 105 connects Honjo to Daisen in the NE, by way of Ouchi.  Highway 107 connects Honjo to
and Yokote in the east, by way of Higashi Yuri.  Highway 108 connects Honjo to

in the SE, by way of Yuri, Yashima and Chokai.  There are several small highways through the mountains, but some of them are seasonal or are closed for long-term repairs, so ask someone locally and check.  In the winter, the roads can be snowy and icy, and the mountain areas — Chokai, for example — get tons of snow.
From Ugohonjo Station in Honjo, the Akebono night train goes direct to Tokyo, and the Nihonkai night train goes direct to Kyoto.  The nearest shinkansen stations are the Komachi Shinkansen in

.  Both of these shinkansen lines go to Tokyo.  There are many daily trains going north and south out of Honjo.  There is also a private train line that goes from Ugohonjo Station to Yashima, by way of Yuri.  See

value: content=The main train station in Yurihonjo.
directions=2 blocks SW of the Yashima Police Station, and well-signed
content=The terminus of the Yuri Kogen Railway.  This station has a large sitting area and a computer with free internet.
alt=由利高原鉄道 Yurikōgen tetsudō
content=This railway runs from Ugohonjo Station to Yashima by way of Yuri.  Trains leave around once an hour; see the website for the schedule.

Night buses go from Tokyo to Yurihonjo.  Several bus companies offer this service.  Check the websites or ask at the bus station for more information.

value: directions=Half a block west of Hotel Iris.
content=Night buses go to and from Tokyo.  There are other bus routes to various places in Akita, as well.
content=The line connecting Honjo and Tokyo is called "Chokai Dream".  Passengers can board at Ugohonjo Station, Ugokotsu Bus Station, and several other locations in the area.
content=Runs nightly buses connecting Honjo and Tokyo.

In Honjo itself, biking and walking are feasible.  There are a few buses each day connecting outlying towns.  Iwaki, Nishime, Yuri, and Yashima can be reached by train from Honjo.  Taxis and daiko are available, but they're very expensive for outlying areas.  Traveling by car is convenient, and parking is rarely a problem.

There are several daily buses connecting Honjo to Higashi-Yuri.  Buses also go from Honjo to Yashima several times a day, continuing to Kawauchi and Jinego in Chokai.  Though there are buses going from Honjo to Iwaki and Nikaho, the train is probably more convenient.  The train station has timetables for local buses.

value: alt=由利本荘市公共交通情報
directions=On Route 69, several kilometers south of the rest area in Ouchi.
alt=本荘文化会館 Honjō bunkakaikan
directions=1 block west of Max Valu and 1 block SW of the large pink hospital
content=This building is the only large auditorium in Yurihonjo.  It hosts many kinds of shows, such as dance shows, concerts, and karaoke contests.
content=Have a picnic.  In April or May, watch cherry blossoms in the park.
alt=法体の滝 Hottai no taki
directions=Follow road signs from Yashima or Kawauchi.

content=A large waterfall with picnic and camping area and restaurant in Momoyake, Hitane, Chokai.  There is also a 2km hiking trail.  The facilities are closed in winter, and the road is not plowed.  However, the road is plowed in Momoyake until the last 2km, so one can easily walk in on snowshoes.
alt=岩城歴史民俗資料館 Iwaki rekishi minzoku shiryōkan
directions=From Honjo, go several kilometers north, and then turn east towards Kameda.  There's a large tower that's visible from afar.

content=This reconstructed village has some museum buildings with old clothes, weapons, scrolls, and, oddly, biology research.  There are also some reconstructed buildings, as well as old looms and blacksmith tools.  Next to the reconstructed village there's a large tower, surrounded by a small moat.  There's a restaurant and gift shop on the first floor, and the top floor has nice views of Kameda.  No English is spoken, but the ticket window has an English language handout that describes each of the buildings.  If the employees have time, they can demonstrate how some of the tools are used.

directions=From the Ouchi Rest Area, take Highway 107 east a few hundred meters, then turn north on Highway 69 and follow it for several kilometers.  There are two parking lots and a small shop at the road, and the statues are just up the hill.
content=See a thousand small statues on a path by the road.

directions=Coming from Honjo, Take Highway 108 past Yashima.  About 10km after Yashima, there is a traffic light and crosswalk.  About 100m after that, turn right.  The ballpark is on the right after 50m.
content=This ballpark hosts youth and adult baseball games.
alt=鳥海高原南由利原スノーモービルランド
content=A snowmobile training and recreation area.  Instructors can teach beginners, including children.  Reservations necessary.
directions=Follow signs from Yashima or Kawauchi.
content=Onsen and hotel on the base of Mt. Chokai.  There are indoor and outdoor baths.  Bring your own towel for bathing.
directions=Follow Japanese road signs from Yashima.
price=Hiking is free.  To stay overnight at the summit lodge, you need to make reservations and pay
from the Haraikawa Trailhead near Yashima.  It takes around 4 hours to reach the summit, or 8 hours round trip.  The mountain is 2236 meters high.
directions=Take Highway 108 to Jinego in Chokai.  At the traffic light, turn west.  Follow the road perhaps 15km to the trail head.  Signs in Japanese.

content=A round trip climb up and down Mt. Hinoto takes around 5 hours.  Get supplies in Jinego before going to the trail head.  For a few kilometers leading to the trail head, the road is unpaved.  The mountain is 1,145 meters high.
directions=Take Highway 70 SE from the Jinego Rest Area on Highway 108.  It's north of the road after perhaps 6km.
alt=オコジョランドスキー場 Okojorando suki-jō
price=Adult day pass ¥2200; adult 4 hour ticket ¥1100
content=Small ski area in Momoyake, Chokai.  1 chair lift (2 person).  Ski rentals available.  There's a restaurant and a large free-use room in the warming house.
directions=From Momoya on Highway 108, drive 200m towards Yuzawa.  Turn left and follow the road for 300m until it runs into the Shisuikan.
content=This community center often hosts public events, such as guest speakers and concerts.
directions=Near Okojoland Ski Area in Sarukura, Hitane.
content=This onsen is part of Hotel Masaka.  It makes a nice stop after skiing at Okojoland Ski Area.

content=Largest library in Yurihonjo.  Some English books are available, but most of these are in a storage room in back, so ask for help.
directions=SW of Honjo Park on top of the hill.
content=This is an outdoor sumo practice ring, open for all to use.  Contact the Honjo Board of Education (number above) for more information.

content=This public building has a small public library, as well as a gym and kitchen.  Private groups often reserve the gym or kitchen and use them for various events.  This building was formerly called the Koiki Koryu Center (広域交流センター).

content=This bath house is part of a hotel.  It's one of the only 24-hour bath houses in Yurihonjo.  The building is not noteworthy, but on the other hand, it's clean, and the bath is large.  There's a large bath, a small mineral bath, a sauna, and an outdoor sitting area.  Massages are available.

The best shopping in Yurihonjo is in Honjo itself.  If Honjo doesn't have what you want, go to
.  If you're shopping in one of the outlying areas, there are often interesting gifts at the rest area shops.

fish is quite popular.  Though unfortunately these foods are only served at a few restaurants around town, they can be purchased at many gift shops.  Yurihonjo itself is known for several brands of sake (Japanese rice wine), such as
).  Sake is served at bars and sold at many convenience and grocery stores.

Kikuchi Ryokan, a small bed & breakfast.

Business hotels are best found in Honjo.  Ryokans can be found throughout Yurihonjo, though for a ryokan you'll want to have reservations or arrive early in the day.  In a pinch, a car traveler could sleep in the car at any of the rest areas — this is quite common in northern Japan.  If you're thinking of sleeping in your car after a night of drinking, please make sure you're completely alcohol-free in the morning, because the police may see your car in the evening and watch for it in the morning.  Additionally, there are a few love hotels that could be used, but regular hotels are comparable in price, so it's not a great option.

value: directions=From the Jinego Rest Area, take Highway 70 SE.  At a T-junction, Highway 70 turns N, but don't follow it -- keep going straight.  After about 5km, the pavement turns to gravel, and the campground is about 3km farther.

content=This isolated campground itself is not very scenic, but it is near the trail head for Hinoto Dake (丁岳), a good day hike.  It has one toilet building, a small area for dish washing, a covered eating area, and a light.  There is no resident caretaker.  The road and campground are closed in winter.
directions=Near Okojoland Ski Area in Sarukura, Hitane.
price=Single room with two meals for ¥8200
directions=Follow signs from Yashima or Kawauchi.
content=Hotel and onsen on the base of Mt. Chokai.  There is a restaurant, a cafe, and a gift shop.  It's about 10 minutes by car to Yashima Ski Area.
directions=Near Okojoland Ski Area in Sarukura, Hitane.
content=Hotel Masaka hosts overnight guests and large enkais.  Yunosawa Onsen is part of this hotel.
directions=50m NE of the Jinego Post Office, on the west side of the street
directions=Located at the top of Mt. Chokai.  This is only accessibly by a several hour hike.

content=This summit hut is popular with hikers who stay the night and get up to see the sun rise from the top of the mountain.  Overnight fare includes a bland dinner and breakfast, so many hikers bring a little extra food.  Reservations highly recommended.  The hut is open from early summer to early October — in that season, the website has relevant pricing reservation information.

directions=Just south of Daiichi Hospital and just north of the library.

content=This hotel is convenient for travelers without a car.
directions=From Honjo Post Office, go one block north and one block west.  The hotel is a tall building that's easy to see.
content=Upscale hotel in central Honjo.  There is a restaurant.
alt=ホテル ルートイン 由利本荘
directions=At the junction of Highway 7 and Highway 107 in Honjo.
content=This hotel has a convenient location for people traveling by car.
directions=From Shinzan Elementary School in northern Honjo, take a small road slightly east to Shinzan Park, and then go several kilometers north.  The campground is on the east side of the road.
content=This campground has tent spaces and a large cabin (with electricity, running water, and kitchen) for rent.  There is also a playground and zip line.

content=This 24-hour hotel and onsen is designed for people on the move.  It's clean, inexpensive, and located on the highway.

price=Camping is free; cheaper lodges for ¥3000 (in total); more expensive lodges for ¥7000 (in total)
content=This facility has a lodge, some sporting equipment, and a campground.

directions=From Yashima, take Highway 32 towards the ski area.  Just before the ski area, turn right and stay on Highway 32.  At the intersection with Highway 58, turn right and stay on Highway 32 again.  The campground is on the right after about 2 kilometers.
price=¥11,000-15,000 for a 5-person cabin, camping for ¥300 per person

price=Single ¥3500, shared room ¥2900, dinner ¥1600, breakfast ¥800, bath for nonguests ¥300, youth hostel bed ¥2700

content=This hotel and neighboring youth hostel are located on the foothills of Mt. Chokai.  A sports complex and a horseback riding area are located nearby.  The youth hostel has rooms that sleep 5 people.

content=This campground has camp sites and cabins.  It also has a nice view of Mt. Chokai.
